```{r setup, include=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE)
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(here)
```

# Data input

```{r}
ces <- read_csv(here("data", "ces3demographics.csv")) %>% 
  clean_names()
```

# Data visualization 

```{r}
ces_graph <- ggplot(data = ces, aes(x = white_percent, y = ces_3_0_score)) +
  geom_hex() +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "plum3", high = "darkorchid4") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "% white population", y = "CES 3.0 score")
ces_graph
```

**Figure 1.** California census tracts with large white populations tend to have lower CES 3.0 scores. Darker color represents greater density of points.
